news.title: Exclusive | ‘Only game in town’: Spain’s Arancha Gonzalez says China, EU can thrive despite Trump 2.0
news.text:
Arancha Gonzalez served as Spain’s foreign minister and is dean of the Paris School of International Affairs, Sciences Po. She was a United Nations assistant secretary general and executive director of the International Trade Centre, the joint trade development agency of the UN, and the World Trade Organization. This interview first appeared in SCMP Plus. For other interviews in the Open Questions series, click here.
You served as foreign minister during the transition from the presidencies of Donald Trump to Joe Biden. With the former president returning to the White House next year, there are still legacies from Trump’s previous foreign policy. What is the biggest concern for the European Union?
We’re going to face three big challenges: trade tariffs, hostility towards climate change and the most important for Europe, which is the desire expressed by the incoming president to resolve the conflict in Ukraine.
And this [Ukraine war] is probably seen from Europe as the most consequential one. First, as Europeans, we believe that this conversation should be with Ukraine and not on Ukraine. And it should be with Europeans and not against Europeans.
For Europeans, the manner in which this conflict is addressed will be the bar of deterrence vis-a-vis Russia, and we do not want this bar to be too low. But more importantly, I think this is a very important question for the [Asia-Pacific] region because it will also be a test of the credibility of the United States as an ally to many countries in this region.
How will the tariffs and climate issues that you mentioned in Trump’s coming presidency affect the EU?
It is pretty clear that there will be tariffs, and that they will be applied to every economy in the world. They will be tougher on China, and they will disrupt the economy. I think they will bring no clear benefits to the US because the problems of the US do not have to do with tariffs.
The problems of inequality in the US will not be solved through tariffs. It should be solved through social safety nets. Until this is done, there will continue to be an increase in inequalities in the US, which tariffs will not prevent.

I have the impression that president-elect Trump sees climate as an ideological issue. But climate change is not an ideological issue. It is about risk management. We in Europe have understood that this is a risk that we need to manage, and we have put in place measures to decarbonise our economies and obviously, we are moving very fast forward.
But this is not enough. We need the rest of the world to continue to do so. I am heartened by the fact that many businesses in America and many states in America have understood that the fight against climate change is not only important from a risk management point of view, but it is also a source of growth for jobs. So I am confident that they will also have a say in the domestic debate in the US.
How do you anticipate China-US relations will evolve over the next four years under Trump’s next administration?
I see two camps. I see the camp of the China hawks in the appointments that Trump has made, and I see others that are a bit more friendly towards China because they are doing business in China. Take the case of Elon Musk.
So whom will the president-elect listen to? It is an open question. What we know is that the overall sentiment in the US towards China is negative. The US is afraid of China’s rise. We all know that China will not sit still if the US takes action against China, which is why I think we should all work to make sure that we do not destabilise the global economy. We should try to manage the relationships and differences that may exist in an adult manner as much as possible.
Trump thinks everything is negotiable. He has no limits for his deal-making. He thinks that everything is up for sale or buying. So it depends on the price that he asks, and it depends on what China is ready to transact. Beijing will have made its calculations. They will be prepared. They will be ready to respond if attacked.
Given your assessment, how will the EU position itself in the China-US rivalry, and how will Brussels engage with Beijing?
The problem of the EU is not Donald Trump. It is Europe’s ability to take its future into its own hands.
The EU needs to integrate further in the areas where it is still fragmented: energy, technology, defence and capital markets. The EU should invest more in its defence given the unpredictability of the incoming US administration, which will also impact Nato.
The EU now needs to find the political will to strengthen its own hand. It’s the only game in town for the EU.
The EU is conscious of the place that China has in the world, especially in the world economy. It understands that China is a systemic actor in the world, and that ensuring financial stability, fair trade, reduction of emissions or the fight against pandemics requires working with China. So this is why the EU has very clearly said it considers China to be a partner, a competitor and a rival. The EU has been very honest about this. China and the EU can maintain these three-pronged approaches.

We will find a lot of difficulties with the incoming US administration, which is more protectionist, but the question is whether Europe and China will decide to go that route too, or whether they will keep the stability of their existing trade relations.
This is not only between China and the EU but also between other countries, including the Asia-Pacific region. If we respect the rules of the game among ourselves, that will give us more strength.
It will be a test. If the US unilaterally imposes tariffs on the rest of the world, then maybe the rest of the world decides not to do this against each other. China and the EU will be essential for this [possibility].
How do you evaluate current trade relations between the EU and China in view of the EU’s concerns about overcapacity, which has cast a long shadow over bilateral trade and investment?
Trade relations could be better. We should always strive for better. From Europe, we see an imbalance in the Chinese economy that concerns us. China’s investments are being made to generate productive capacity, in excess of what its domestic market can absorb, and it is ending up in the international markets.
And if we assume that the US will be less open to China in the future, the concern is: will this overcapacity end up in the European Union? This is not only a concern for the EU – other countries around the world share these concerns.
But at the heart, it is a decision on the Chinese side about its own growth model. The model we see is that Chinese citizens save disproportionately compared to what they consume. Domestic consumption is subdued; it does not contribute enough to the growth of the country, which then disproportionately relies on exports for its own growth.
I think part of the question is: why is the Chinese consumer so reluctant to consume? Part of the answer is because China has weak social safety nets. It has a weaker healthcare system, pension system, education system – elements that make the Chinese consumer be very conservative.
There may be an interesting dialogue to be had between the EU and China, just to share experiences of how one can build stronger safety nets at home that give comfort to the consumer, so that it can ignite consumption and then rely less only on exports as a means to boost the economy domestically.
The US-China trade war started in January 2018. China is disputing through the World Trade Organization an EU move to impose extra tariffs on EVs. How close are China and Europe to a trade war, and what are the potential outcomes?
I see a fundamental difference between the China-US situation where the first Trump administration – and Biden maintained them – essentially imposed discriminatory tariffs on China in disregard of WTO rules, and the measures adopted by the EU against China which have always sought to respect WTO rules. It is protectionism versus fair trade.

Europe opened an investigation against Chinese exports of EVs and found that they were being unfairly subsidised, which led to the imposition of tariffs. China is in its right to contest this decision in the WTO. It shows that differences in views can be addressed within the framework of established procedures rather than “shooting from the hip”. Now, both sides have a chance to find a negotiated outcome. If they do not, tariffs will remain for as long as the unfair subsidies remain.
There seems to be a mutual perception between Europe and China of each being a potential disrupter of the international trading system. How should organisations like the WTO and the International Trade Centre navigate these challenges?
If, as announced, incoming president Trump imposes tariffs on global trade, we will see major disruptions on trade. Europe and China will have to make a strategic choice: join and amplify the chaos or contribute to stabilising the situation, working together and with other trading partners around the world. Working to preserve the WTO. For the latter, both would need to play by the rules.
So, isn’t the EU’s “de-risking” strategy towards China another major concern in bilateral economic ties?
Let us say that China is de-risking from the EU too. The dual circulation is no less than a de-risking strategy. China has realised that it has to be more selective about its engagement with the rest of the world.
The EU also has understood that this is a world where trade is weaponised, and power and rivalry weigh over efficiency and the economy. The EU has to be careful about it.
“Once bitten, twice shy” is what we have also experienced with EU trade, whether it is energy, trade or critical raw materials being weaponised.
Does it mean that the EU is less open? No, the EU has not closed its markets, but it is more selective about where to engage and how to engage. The EU is doing exactly what China is doing, which is managing its trade relations in a more careful manner. I think this is the right strategy.
Germany’s investment value in China grew in 2023, which shows that the point is not to disconnect from China. Europe is not disconnecting from China. Europe is better at managing the risks that an excessive reliance on a single product, or in a single country, can bring to its economy.
Nearly three years after Russia invaded Ukraine, how does the EU currently perceive China’s role and its growing ties with Russia?
For the EU, Beijing’s move towards Russia is an important concern. We do not see the Ukraine war, only a European war. We see Ukraine war as a test of what [in the world] can go wrong. Because it means countries are allowed to invade other countries freely.
When we see North Korean soldiers fighting on the Russian front against Ukraine, we see that there is a linkage between those theatres. It is not just the European conflict. It is a conflict that now connects the Atlantic and Indo-Pacific.
It is important to explain this and to ensure everyone understands that when the rules of the game are not respected in Europe, the rules will not be respected anywhere else in the world. And that worries us, and we do not want that.
Finnish President Alexander Stubb once suggested “one phone call from President Xi Jinping would solve this [Ukraine] crisis”. Do you believe China holds such a significant role in this matter, and what can Brussels expect Beijing to do?
Countries are free to do what they want. But what we have been saying to China, is that for us, it is important to ensure that international law is respected. We are telling countries what would make for a better relationship with the EU, and I think it is fair to do that.
It is not for the European Union to tell President Xi Jinping what he has to do. But if Xi thinks that the relationship between China and the EU is a valuable one, using his capacity to influence [Russian] President Vladimir Putin would be very valuable too.
We are saying this because we think that what is happening in Ukraine is not just a European problem. It is symptomatic of what can go wrong internationally. It happened to Ukraine. It can happen anywhere else in the world.
Beijing is also concerned about Nato’s close cooperation with its Indo-Pacific partners. Could this source of tension escalate into a security flashpoint between China and the EU?
It is very clear – the centre of gravity of Nato is the North Atlantic region. But there are risks that we have also identified, for example, risks to freedom of navigation. This is a big issue for us, because we [Europe] are a big trading continent, and we have identified this as being a concern that other countries in this region share. So we exchange with those countries.
Is this anti-China? No, it is pro-freedom of navigation. For a continent that relies on two-thirds of its growth from international trade, it is pretty clear that that is a concern that we have.
It is important to understand what is driving the collaboration of the EU and Nato, first and foremost, is our security in the Atlantic, and our security and capability to respond to the attacks that we are receiving from Russia, directly into Ukraine, and indirectly, cyberattacks, sabotage of major infrastructure, disinformation campaigns that we are also suffering from Russia. So that is how we see Nato.
But we also see other risks. We’ve put this on the most recent strategy that Nato adopted in Madrid last year, where we see threats to cybersecurity, threats to navigation, terrorism and climate change. These are also important for us to manage together in the alliance and with partners around the world.
Since Beijing exempted visa requirements for most European countries, there seems to have been an increase in European tourists, especially students, to China. Can these people-to-people exchanges help improve mutual understanding?
I think for the future, a big part of stabilising the relationship between Europe and China will be to make sure that we understand each other, our students can study in both jurisdictions, our businesspeople can travel freely, our tourists can move back and forth, that is how we build resilience in our relationship.
As the dean of the Paris School of International Affairs at Sciences Po in France, I value the partnerships we have with many Chinese universities, especially after the commitment to student exchanges agreed during President Xi’s visit with [French] President Emmanuel Macron.
The education exchanges and student exchanges are at the heart of our project for the next few years. I do hope that we keep these people-to-people exchanges, because they are important in helping each side understand the other and therefore build resilience, especially when the political levels sometimes find it more difficult.
Do flourishing people-to-people exchanges help to make China a friendlier environment for foreigners?
The Covid-19 pandemic was a turning point for the presence of foreign students and foreign businesses in China. We’ve seen a decrease in the numbers. It probably had to do with a desire by students and foreign Europeans living in China to be closer to their families in Europe, given the prolonged period of Covid-19 restrictions. But the situation has not really gone back to what it was.
So in my view, this is an area where what should be done is to improve people-to-people relations, which again, is the bedrock of renewing relationships.
Spain has abstained from a vote to impose an extra EV tariff. It would be severely impacted if an investigation revealed that the EU’s pork exports to China violated trade rules. Does this suggest Spain will have its own pragmatic approach to China relations?
Spain is an example in the EU of a country that relies a lot on international trade for its growth, whether it is trading goods or trading services. Therefore we want to make sure that trade relations with major trading partners, including the US and certainly including China, are as smooth as possible.
Secondly, because China is a big trading partner for Spain, Spain wants trade to be conducted under fair trading conditions.
Thirdly, if there is no alternative, Spain generally supports Europe taking protective measures, but the preference is for open markets with rules of the game.
Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said during his meeting with Xi Jinping in September that Spain wants to work constructively for closer China-EU relations. What can Spain do to achieve that goal?
Spain and China have a pretty decent cooperation record. We trade with each other. We invest in each other. Probably there are a little bit more Chinese investments in Spain than Spanish investments in China. There are lots of spaces on the cultural side too.
By and large, we have relatively solid, constructive approaches. Can we have more? Probably, yes, which does not mean that we do not tell each other things that we think need to be improved in the relationship, for example, fairness in trade, and freedom of navigation.
But we generally tend to say those things privately rather than trumpeting them publicly, because we believe this is perhaps a more conducive way of doing that. We do not shy away from saying the things to each other that we do not like.
